title: 107_hr4141
content: The Act is titled the "Red Rock Canyon National Conservation Area Protection and Enhancement Act of 2002". It defines terms like "Corporation", "Red Rock", "Red Rock Map", and "Secretary". The Congress finds Red Rock as a significant natural resource that must be protected for future generations. The Corporation owns land on Red Rock's eastern boundary and is developing a master-planned community. Included in their holdings are 1,071 acres of high-ground lands intended for Red Rock, which would preserve the western Las Vegas Valley view-shed. The Corporation owns high-ground lands near Red Rock in the western Las Vegas Valley view-shed. They propose the United States acquire the lands to protect and expand Red Rock, in exchange for other lands of equal value. This aligns with the goals of the Bureau of Land Management and previous conservation acts. The Corporation owns high-ground lands near Red Rock in the western Las Vegas Valley view-shed and proposes a land exchange with the United States to protect and expand Red Rock. The Corporation offers to convey approximately 1,082 acres of nonfederal land to the United States for incorporation into the NCA. In exchange, the Corporation will receive approximately 998 acres of Federal lands, and Clark County, Nevada will receive approximately 1,221 acres of Federal lands for a park. Title to the private and Federal properties will be conveyed simultaneously. The Red Rock Map will be kept on file for public inspection in Nevada. The Secretary will keep the Red Rock Map on file for public inspection in Nevada. Conditions for the conveyance include the Corporation being responsible for hazardous materials removal and providing a survey of the common boundary within 90 days. The Secretary will require that lands conveyed to Clark County must be held in perpetuity for public park use or as part of a regional trail system. If the County attempts to use the lands inconsistently, they will revert to the United States. The lands conveyed to Clark County must be held in perpetuity for public park use or as part of a regional trail system. If the County uses the lands inconsistently, they will revert to the United States. SEC. 5. STATUS AND MANAGEMENT OF LANDS. Upon enactment of this Act, the Secretary will administer the Flood Control Detention Basin Lands depicted on the Red Rock Map as part of Red Rock in accordance with relevant laws. Acquired lands will also be administered as part of Red Rock, with new maps reflecting boundary adjustments available for review at the Las Vegas District Office. The Red Rock boundaries will be modified as per the Act, with new maps available for review at the Bureau of Land Management offices. A conforming amendment includes additional areas in the conservation area. SEC. 6. GENERAL PROVISIONS. The Secretary will review an appraisal and any difference in values will be reimbursed. The land exchange will respect valid existing rights. Parties can correct technical errors in the Red Rock Map. The Secretary will withdraw affected lands from public land and mining laws. The Secretary will withdraw Federal lands acquired or owned by the United States within the Red Rock National Conservation Area boundaries from public land and mining laws, correcting technical errors in the Red Rock Map. The House of Representatives passed the bill on October 1, 2002.
